Optimal hybrid block bootstrap for sample quantiles under weak dependence

Todd A. Kuffner
Department of Mathematics
Washington University in St. Louis
kuffner@wustl.edu

Stephen M.S. Lee
Department of Statistics and Actuarial Science
The University of Hong Kong
smslee@hku.hk

G. Alastair Young
Department of Mathematics
Imperial College London
alastair.young@imperial.ac.uk
Abstract

We establish a general theory of optimality for block bootstrap distribution estimation for sample quantiles under a mild strong mixing assumption. In contrast to existing results, we study the block bootstrap for varying numbers of blocks. This corresponds to a hybrid between the subsampling bootstrap and the moving block bootstrap (MBB), in which the number of blocks is somewhere between 1 and the ratio of sample size to block length. Our main theorem determines the optimal choice of the number of blocks and block length to achieve the best possible convergence rate for the block bootstrap distribution estimator for sample quantiles. As part of our analysis, we also prove an important lemma which gives the convergence rate of the block bootstrap distribution estimator, with implications even for the smooth function model. We propose an intuitive procedure for empirical selection of the optimal number and length of blocks. Relevant examples are presented which illustrate the benefits of optimally choosing the number of blocks.

Keywords and phrases: Hybrid block bootstrap; subsampling; optimality; sample quantile; weak dependence; strong mixing.

1 Introduction

A broad categorization of settings for bootstrap methods might be as follows: (i) smooth functionals of independent data; (ii) nonsmooth functionals of independent data; (iii) smooth functionals of dependent data; and (iv) nonsmooth functionals of dependent data. Setting (i) is the classic setting of the bootstrap, with Hall (1992) being an authoritative reference. In setting (ii), bootstrap methods for approximating distributions of sample quantiles have been studied by Efron (1979); Bickel and Freedman (1981); Singh (1981); Babu (1986); Efron (1982); Ghosh et al. (1984); Hall and Sheather (1988); Hall et al. (1989); Hall and Martin (1991); De Angelis et al. (1993) and Falk and Janas (1992).

In setting (iii), the existing literature is concentrated on block bootstrap methods for smooth functionals with dependent data, beginning with Hall (1985), and Carlstein (1986). Subsequently, the moving block bootstrap (MBB) was proposed by Künsch (1989) and Liu and Singh (1992). Other variants and properties of block bootstrap methods were considered by Paparoditis and Politis (2001); Politis and Romano (1992, 1994) and Politis et al. (1997), to name a few. In setting (iii), various block bootstrap methods and their properties for weakly dependent sequences have been investigated by, for example, Bühlmann (1994); Naik-Nimbalkar and Rajarshi (1994); Hall et al. (1995); Götze and Künsch (1996); Lahiri (1992, 1996, 1999) and Bühlmann and Künsch (1999).

In contrast, there is a less extensive literature about block bootstrap methods in setting (iv), i.e. for nonsmooth functions of dependent data. Sun and Lahiri (2006), Sun (2007) and Sharipov and Wendler (2013) are notable exceptions. Those authors considered block bootstrap approximation for sample quantiles under weak dependence. Sun and Lahiri (2006) established strong consistency of the MBB, assuming only a polynomial (strong) mixing rate, for both distribution and variance estimation of the sample quantiles. Sharipov and Wendler (2013) established similar results for the circular block bootstrap utilizing a different set of conditions to take advantage of empirical process theory for the Bahadur-Ghosh representation of the sample quantile. Sun (2007) is particularly relevant to our work, as discussed further below. All of these earlier results assume that the number of blocks tends to infinity with the sample size.

More recently, Kuffner et al. (2017) established a more general consistency result for a hybrid block bootstrap, for both distribution and variance estimation of sample quantiles. While an exponential mixing rate is assumed, Kuffner et al. (2017) proved weak consistency for any number of blocks, 1≤b=O​(n/ℓ)1𝑏𝑂𝑛ℓ1\leq b=O(n/\ell) (as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty), whereas the existing proofs for the MBB and circular block bootstrap required that b→∞→𝑏b\rightarrow\infty, where b=⌊n/ℓ⌋𝑏𝑛ℓb=\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor. Here, n𝑛n is the available sample size, and ℓℓ\ell is the block length. The value of b𝑏b is the number of resampled blocks to be pasted to form the bootstrap data series. The case b=1𝑏1b=1 corresponds to the subsampling bootstrap (Politis and Romano, 1994), and the case b=⌊n/ℓ⌋𝑏𝑛ℓb=\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor is the standard MBB (Künsch, 1989). Therefore, the consistency results in Kuffner et al. (2017) are for a ‘hybrid’ between the MBB and the subsampling bootstrap, and those two extremes are covered by the same theory.

As noted in Kuffner et al. (2017), their theoretical and empirical results suggest that there can be substantial performance improvement, in terms of mean squared errors (MSE) for both the variance and distribution estimators, when choosing some value of b>1𝑏1b>1, but less than ⌊n/ℓ⌋𝑛ℓ\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor. This suggests the following question: does there exist some optimal choice of the pair (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) which provides the best convergence rate for the bootstrap distribution estimator for sample quantiles under weak dependence? We answer that question in the present paper.

Related to the motivation of the present paper is the paper by Sun (2007). She studied the convergence rate of the moving block bootstrap distribution estimator for sample quantiles with dependent data. A strong mixing condition with exponentially decaying mixing coefficients was assumed. An almost sure convergence result was established, and the best rate of convergence was found to be O​(n−1/4​log⁡log⁡n)𝑂superscript𝑛14𝑛O(n^{-1/4}\log\log n). We consider a weaker polynomial rate condition, which is also slightly weaker than that assumed in Sun and Lahiri (2006). Moreover, we allow the number of blocks to vary, instead of fixing b=⌊n/ℓ⌋𝑏𝑛ℓb=\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor. Our main theorem establishes the convergence rate of the ‘hybrid’ bootstrap distribution estimator for sample quantiles. It is a hybrid between the MBB (b=⌊n/ℓ⌋𝑏𝑛ℓb=\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor) and subsampling (b=1𝑏1b=1) bootstrap. We also apply our theory to the setting of Sun (2007) below.

Another recent development in dependent data bootstrap methodology is the convolved subsampling bootstrap (Tewes et al., 2017). This bootstrap estimator is defined by the k𝑘k-fold self-convolution of a subsampling distribution. In the special case of the sample means problem, this corresponds to our hybrid bootstrap. For the sample quantile problem which is the particular focus here, convolved subsampling bootstrap essentially computes the average of within-block sample quantiles over the b𝑏b resampled blocks. By contrast, our estimator is the sample quantile of a single series formed by joining b𝑏b blocks. Further theoretical comparison of these approaches will be undertaken elsewhere.

Other indirectly-related work includes Lahiri (2005), who studied consistency of jackknife-after-bootstrap variance estimation for bootstrap quantiles, and Gregory et al. (2015), who showed that the Sun and Lahiri (2006) strong consistency results for distribution and variance estimation via the MBB also hold for the smoothed extended tapered block bootstrap (SETBB). We mention that Shao and Politis (2013) employed a fixed b𝑏b subsampling procedure to estimate confidence sets for statistics adhering to the smooth function model, which of course does not include sample quantiles.

Aside from our general optimality results being of foundational and practical value, they also indicate that adaptive selection of the number of blocks could yield considerable improvements in convergence rates for block bootstrap distribution estimators. Moreover, Lemma 5 below is of independent interest, as it gives the convergence rate of the block bootstrap distribution estimator, and has bearing on the regular smooth function model. We have included several relevant empirical examples to illustrate the potential gains of optimal choice of the number of blocks, as opposed to using the prescribed value of b𝑏b for either the subsampling bootstrap (b=1)𝑏1(b=1) or the MBB (b=⌊n/ℓ⌋𝑏𝑛ℓb=\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor). In § 5, we give practical guidance as to how to choose (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) in a given applied problem, by proposing a procedure for this purpose.

2 Problem Setting

Let ℤ≡{0,±1,±2,…}ℤ0plus-or-minus1plus-or-minus2…\mathbb{Z}\equiv\{0,\pm 1,\pm 2,\ldots\} be the set of all integers. Define {Xi}i∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑖ℤ\{X_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}} to be a doubly-infinite sequence of random variables on the probability space (Ω,ℱ,P)Ωℱ𝑃(\Omega,\mathcal{F},P). The elements of the sequence possess a common distribution function F𝐹F, and its corresponding quantile function F−1superscript𝐹1F^{-1}, defined by

F−1​(p)=inf{u:F​(u)≥p},p∈(0,1).formulae-sequencesuperscript𝐹1𝑝infimumconditional-set𝑢𝐹𝑢𝑝𝑝01F^{-1}(p)=\inf\{u:F(u)\geq p\},\qquad p\in(0,1).

We will study the block bootstrap distribution estimator of a suitably centered and scaled sample quantile. It is assumed throughout that {Xi}i∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑖ℤ\{X_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}} is a strictly stationary process. The sequence (X1,…,Xn)subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}) denotes a sample of size n𝑛n from {Xi}i∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑖ℤ\{X_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}.

2.1 The Block Bootstrap

The moving blocks bootstrap (MBB) (Künsch, 1989) splits the original sample (X1,…,Xn)subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}) into overlapping blocks of size ℓℓ\ell, Bi=(Xi,…,Xi+ℓ−1)subscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝑋𝑖…subscript𝑋𝑖ℓ1B_{i}=(X_{i},\ldots,X_{i+\ell-1}), together constituting a set {B1,…,Bn−ℓ+1}subscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑛ℓ1\{B_{1},\ldots,B_{n-\ell+1}\}. Let B1∗,…,Bb∗superscriptsubscript𝐵1…superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑏B_{1}^{*},\ldots,B_{b}^{*} be a random sample drawn with replacement from the original blocks, where b=⌊n/ℓ⌋𝑏𝑛ℓb=\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor is the number of blocks that will be pasted together to form a pseudo-time series. For a real number hℎh, the notation ⌊h⌋ℎ\lfloor h\rfloor is defined as the largest integer ≤habsentℎ\leq h, and ⌈h⌉ℎ\lceil h\rceil is the smallest integer ≥habsentℎ\geq h. That B1∗,…,Bb∗superscriptsubscript𝐵1…superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑏B_{1}^{*},\ldots,B_{b}^{*} is a random sample from {B1,…,Bn−ℓ+1}subscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑛ℓ1\{B_{1},\ldots,B_{n-\ell+1}\} means that the sampled blocks are independently and identically distributed according to a discrete uniform distribution on {B1,…,Bn−ℓ+1}subscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑛ℓ1\{B_{1},\ldots,B_{n-\ell+1}\}. The observations in the i𝑖ith resampled block, Bi∗superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}^{*}, are X(i−1)​ℓ+1∗,…,Xi​ℓ∗superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖1ℓ1…superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖ℓX_{(i-1)\ell+1}^{*},\ldots,X_{i\ell}^{*}, for 1≤i≤b1𝑖𝑏1\leq i\leq b. Then the MBB sample is the concatenation of the resampled blocks, written as

X1∗,…,Xℓ∗⏟B1∗,Xℓ+1∗,…,X2​ℓ∗⏟B2∗,X2​ℓ+1∗,…,X(b−1)​ℓ∗⏟B3∗​…​B(b−1)∗,X(b−1)​ℓ+1∗,…,Xb​ℓ∗⏟Bb∗.subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝑋1…superscriptsubscript𝑋ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐵1subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝑋ℓ1…superscriptsubscript𝑋2ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐵2subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝑋2ℓ1…superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑏1ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐵3…superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑏1subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑏1ℓ1…superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑏ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑏\underbrace{X_{1}^{*},\ldots,X_{\ell}^{*}}_{B_{1}^{*}},\underbrace{X_{\ell+1}^{*},\ldots,X_{2\ell}^{*}}_{B_{2}^{*}},\underbrace{X_{2\ell+1}^{*},\ldots,X_{(b-1)\ell}^{*}}_{B_{3}^{*}\ldots B_{(b-1)}^{*}},\underbrace{X_{(b-1)\ell+1}^{*},\ldots,X_{b\ell}^{*}}_{B_{b}^{*}}.

Note that this way of constructing the pseudo-time series will reproduce the original dependence structure asymptotically.

The subsampling bootstrap (Politis and Romano, 1994), and specifically the overlapping blocks version relevant to the present setting, first splits the original sample into precisely the same overlapping blocks as the MBB, each of length ℓℓ\ell. However, the subsampling bootstrap draws only a single block. A nice property of this procedure is that the original dependence structure in the sample is exactly retained in the single subsample. By contrast, the pseudo-time series constructed by the MBB only reproduces the original dependence structure asymptotically.

We define dependence for the sequence of random variables {Xi}i∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑖ℤ\{X_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}} in terms of the mixing properties of σ𝜎\sigma-algebras generated by subsets of the sequence which are separated by a distance, in units of time, tending to infinity. For any two sub-σ𝜎\sigma-algebras of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, say ℱ1subscriptℱ1\mathcal{F}_{1} and ℱ2subscriptℱ2\mathcal{F}_{2}, the α𝛼\alpha-mixing coefficient between ℱ1subscriptℱ1\mathcal{F}_{1} and ℱ2subscriptℱ2\mathcal{F}_{2} is defined to be (Athreya and Lahiri, 2006, Section 16.2.1)

α​(ℱ1,ℱ2)≡supA∈ℱ1,B∈ℱ2|P​(A∩B)−P​(A)​P​(B)|.𝛼subscriptℱ1subscriptℱ2subscriptsupremumformulae-sequence𝐴subscriptℱ1𝐵subscriptℱ2𝑃𝐴𝐵𝑃𝐴𝑃𝐵\alpha(\mathcal{F}_{1},\mathcal{F}_{2})\equiv\sup_{A\in\mathcal{F}_{1},B\in\mathcal{F}_{2}}|P(A\cap B)-P(A)P(B)|. (1)

Write ℱkk+tsuperscriptsubscriptℱ𝑘𝑘𝑡\mathcal{F}_{k}^{k+t} for the smallest σ𝜎\sigma-algebra of subsets of ΩΩ\Omega with respect to which Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}, i=k,…,k+t𝑖𝑘…𝑘𝑡i=k,\ldots,k+t, are measurable. Let ℱ−∞ksuperscriptsubscriptℱ𝑘\mathcal{F}_{-\infty}^{k} be the smallest σ𝜎\sigma-algebra which contains the unions of all of the σ𝜎\sigma-algebras ℱaksuperscriptsubscriptℱ𝑎𝑘\mathcal{F}_{a}^{k} as a→−∞→𝑎a\rightarrow-\infty. That is, ℱ−∞ksuperscriptsubscriptℱ𝑘\mathcal{F}_{-\infty}^{k} is a sub-σ𝜎\sigma-algebra of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, and it is the σ𝜎\sigma-algebra generated by the random variables Xa,Xa+1,…,Xksubscript𝑋𝑎subscript𝑋𝑎1…subscript𝑋𝑘X_{a},X_{a+1},\ldots,X_{k} as a→−∞→𝑎a\rightarrow-\infty. Similarly, for −∞≤k≤∞𝑘-\infty\leq k\leq\infty, let ℱk∞superscriptsubscriptℱ𝑘\mathcal{F}_{k}^{\infty} be the σ𝜎\sigma-algebra generated by the random variables Xk+1,Xk+2,…,Xk+asubscript𝑋𝑘1subscript𝑋𝑘2…subscript𝑋𝑘𝑎X_{k+1},X_{k+2},\ldots,X_{k+a}, as a→∞→𝑎a\rightarrow\infty. The α𝛼\alpha-mixing coefficient of the sequence {Xi}i∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑖ℤ\{X_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}} is defined as

α​(t)≡supk∈ℤα​(ℱ−∞k,ℱk+t∞),𝛼𝑡subscriptsupremum𝑘ℤ𝛼superscriptsubscriptℱ𝑘superscriptsubscriptℱ𝑘𝑡\alpha(t)\equiv\sup_{k\in\mathbb{Z}}\alpha(\mathcal{F}_{-\infty}^{k},\mathcal{F}_{k+t}^{\infty}),

where α​(⋅,⋅)𝛼⋅⋅\alpha(\cdot,\cdot) is defined in (1). If the α𝛼\alpha-mixing coefficient decays to zero,

limt→∞α​(t)=0,subscript→𝑡𝛼𝑡0\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\alpha(t)=0, (2)

then the process {Xi}i∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑖ℤ\{X_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}} is said to be strongly mixing. The sequence of random variables {Xi}i∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑖ℤ\{X_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}} is said to be weakly dependent if the process {Xi}i∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑖ℤ\{X_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}} is strongly mixing, i.e. if (2) holds.

3 Theoretical Results

    If β=∞𝛽\beta=\infty, then

    ℙ​(b​ℓ​(ξn∗−ξ~n)≤x|X1,…,Xn)ℙ𝑏ℓsubscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑛subscript~𝜉𝑛conditional𝑥subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛\displaystyle{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{b\ell}\big{(}\xi^{*}_{n}-\tilde{\xi}_{n}\big{)}\leq x\Big{|}X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}\Big{)}
    =\displaystyle= ℙ(n(ξ^n−ξp)≤x)+Op(ℓ−1+ℓ1/2n−1/2+(bℓ)−1/2\displaystyle{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{n}\big{(}\hat{\xi}_{n}-\xi_{p}\big{)}\leq x\Big{)}+O_{p}\Big{(}\ell^{-1}+\ell^{1/2}n^{-1/2}+(b\ell)^{-1/2}
    +n−1b12−δℓ1+5​δ+n−12+δ(bℓ)(1−δ)/4)\displaystyle\qquad+\,n^{-1}b^{\frac{1}{2}-\delta}\ell^{1+5\delta}+n^{-\frac{1}{2}+\delta}(b\ell)^{(1-\delta)/4}\Big{)}
    +op​(n−34+δ​(b​ℓ)1/2+n−1+δ​b12​ℓ).subscript𝑜𝑝superscript𝑛34𝛿superscript𝑏ℓ12superscript𝑛1𝛿superscript𝑏12ℓ\displaystyle\qquad+\,o_{p}\Big{(}n^{-\frac{3}{4}+\delta}(b\ell)^{1/2}+n^{-1+\delta}b^{\frac{1}{2}}\ell\Big{)}.

We may deduce from Theorem 1 the following:

Case (i).

β∈(5,∞)𝛽5\beta\in(5,\infty) and ℓ=O​(b)ℓ𝑂𝑏\ell=O(b).

The convergence rate of the bootstrap distribution estimator is minimised by setting

ℓ∝b∝{n4​β+76​(3​β+5)​log⁡n,β∈(5,(7+185)/4],nβ−13​(β+1),β∈(7+185)/4,∞),\ell\propto b\propto\begin{cases}n^{\frac{4\beta+7}{6(3\beta+5)}}\log n,&\beta\in\big{(}5,(7+\sqrt{185})/4\big{]},\\ n^{\frac{\beta-1}{3(\beta+1)}},&\beta\in\big{(}7+\sqrt{185})/4,\infty\big{)},\end{cases}

which yields, for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0,

ℙ​(b​ℓ​(ξn∗−ξ~n)≤x|X1,…,Xn)−ℙ​(n​(ξ^n−ξp)≤x)ℙ𝑏ℓsubscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑛subscript~𝜉𝑛conditional𝑥subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛ℙ𝑛subscript^𝜉𝑛subscript𝜉𝑝𝑥\displaystyle{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{b\ell}\big{(}\xi^{*}_{n}-\tilde{\xi}_{n}\big{)}\leq x\Big{|}X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}\Big{)}-{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{n}\big{(}\hat{\xi}_{n}-\xi_{p}\big{)}\leq x\Big{)} (3)
=\displaystyle= {Op​(n−14​β2+β−3712​(3​β+5)​(β+1)+δ),β∈(5,(7+185)/4],Op​(n−β−13​(β+1)+δ),β∈(7+185)/4,∞).\displaystyle\begin{cases}O_{p}\left(n^{-\frac{14\beta^{2}+\beta-37}{12(3\beta+5)(\beta+1)}+\delta}\right),&\beta\in\big{(}5,(7+\sqrt{185})/4\big{]},\\ O_{p}\left(n^{-\frac{\beta-1}{3(\beta+1)}+\delta}\right),&\beta\in\big{(}7+\sqrt{185})/4,\infty\big{)}.\end{cases}

Note that as β→∞→𝛽\beta\rightarrow\infty, the optimal orders of ℓℓ\ell and b𝑏b approach n1/3superscript𝑛13n^{1/3}, which does not depend on unknown parameters and may be taken as a practical reference for empirical choices of ℓℓ\ell and b𝑏b. With such choices, that is ℓ∝b∝n1/3proportional-toℓ𝑏proportional-tosuperscript𝑛13\ell\propto b\propto n^{1/3}, the bootstrap distribution estimator has the convergence rate Op​(n−β−23​(β+1)+δ)subscript𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛𝛽23𝛽1𝛿O_{p}\left(n^{-\frac{\beta-2}{3(\beta+1)}+\delta}\right), for β∈(5,∞)𝛽5\beta\in(5,\infty) and any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0. The latter convergence rate is slightly slower than that specified in (3), a price to pay for the absence of knowledge of β𝛽\beta.

On the other hand, the MBB sets b=⌊n/ℓ⌋𝑏𝑛ℓb=\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor, based on which the optimal ℓℓ\ell is of order n1/3superscript𝑛13n^{1/3}, so that b∝n2/3proportional-to𝑏superscript𝑛23b\propto n^{2/3}. The convergence rate of the resulting bootstrap distribution estimator is given, for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, by

{Op​(n−β−52​(β−1)+δ),β∈(5,2+17],Op​(n−β−34​(β+1)+δ),β∈(2+17,∞),casessubscript𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛𝛽52𝛽1𝛿𝛽5217subscript𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛𝛽34𝛽1𝛿𝛽217\begin{cases}O_{p}\left(n^{-\frac{\beta-5}{2(\beta-1)}+\delta}\right),&\beta\in\big{(}5,2+\sqrt{17}\,\big{]},\\ O_{p}\left(n^{-\frac{\beta-3}{4(\beta+1)}+\delta}\right),&\beta\in\big{(}2+\sqrt{17},\infty\big{)},\end{cases}

which is markedly slower than that obtained by setting ℓ∝b∝n1/3proportional-toℓ𝑏proportional-tosuperscript𝑛13\ell\propto b\propto n^{1/3}.

Figure 1 compares the optimal convergence rate with those based on b∝ℓ∝n1/3proportional-to𝑏ℓproportional-tosuperscript𝑛13b\propto\ell\propto n^{1/3} and b=⌊n/ℓ⌋∝n2/3𝑏𝑛ℓproportional-tosuperscript𝑛23b=\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor\propto n^{2/3}, respectively.

Case (ii).

β=∞𝛽\beta=\infty.

The error rate has an order minimised by setting ℓ∝b∝n1/3proportional-toℓ𝑏proportional-tosuperscript𝑛13\ell\propto b\propto n^{1/3}, which yields

ℙ​(b​ℓ​(ξn∗−ξ~n)≤x|X1,…,Xn)=ℙ​(n​(ξ^n−ξp)≤x)+Op​(n−1/3+δ),ℙ𝑏ℓsubscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑛subscript~𝜉𝑛conditional𝑥subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛ℙ𝑛subscript^𝜉𝑛subscript𝜉𝑝𝑥subscript𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛13𝛿{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{b\ell}\big{(}\xi^{*}_{n}-\tilde{\xi}_{n}\big{)}\leq x\Big{|}X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}\Big{)}={\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{n}\big{(}\hat{\xi}_{n}-\xi_{p}\big{)}\leq x\Big{)}+O_{p}\Big{(}n^{-1/3+\delta}\Big{)},

for any arbitrarily small δ>0𝛿0\delta>0. For MBB, the error rate is minimised if ℓℓ\ell is chosen to have order between n1/4superscript𝑛14n^{1/4} and n1/2superscript𝑛12n^{1/2}, yielding an optimal convergence rate of order Op​(n−1/4+δ)subscript𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛14𝛿O_{p}\left(n^{-1/4+\delta}\right) for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0. If we set b=1𝑏1b=1, which amounts to the subsampling method, then the fastest error rate has order Op​(n−1/4)subscript𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛14O_{p}\big{(}n^{-1/4}\big{)}, attained by setting ℓ∝n1/2proportional-toℓsuperscript𝑛12\ell\propto n^{1/2}.

Remark 1.

Case (ii) applies to any strong mixing setting where the mixing coefficients decay faster than any finite polynomial rate. Namely, this includes the exponential rate of Sun (2007), and anything faster. The case that β=∞𝛽\beta=\infty could be replaced by an assumption that the mixing coefficient satisfies α​(t)=O​(e−C​t)𝛼𝑡𝑂superscript𝑒𝐶𝑡\alpha(t)=O(e^{-Ct}) as t→∞→𝑡t\rightarrow\infty, for some C>0𝐶0C>0. This is the assumption in Kuffner et al. (2017), which is equivalent to the condition in Sun (2007). Under such an exponential rate condition, the results for Case (ii) would still hold. However, this would unnecessarily exclude any rate that is faster than polynomial but slower than exponential. We emphasize that Sun (2007) proved an almost sure convergence result under this exponential rate condition, using only the MBB choices of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell).

Remark 2.

Of independent interest is the result of Lemma 5, which gives the convergence rate of the block bootstrap distribution estimator for n​(Fn​(x)−F​(x))𝑛subscript𝐹𝑛𝑥𝐹𝑥\sqrt{n}\big{(}F_{n}(x)-F(x)\big{)} and has a bearing on the regular smooth function model. Consider the simpler case where β=∞𝛽\beta=\infty. It is easily seen that the convergence rate is minimised at Op​(n−1/3)subscript𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛13O_{p}(n^{-1/3}), attained by setting ℓ∝n1/3proportional-toℓsuperscript𝑛13\ell\propto n^{1/3} and b𝑏b having order not smaller than n1/3superscript𝑛13n^{1/3}, of which MBB is a special case. The subsampling method (b=1𝑏1b=1), however, has at best a convergence rate of only order Op​(n−1/4)subscript𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛14O_{p}(n^{-1/4}), attained by setting ℓ∝n1/2proportional-toℓsuperscript𝑛12\ell\propto n^{1/2}.

Remark 3.

Results on distribution estimation for n​(ξ^n−ξp)𝑛subscript^𝜉𝑛subscript𝜉𝑝\sqrt{n}\big{(}\hat{\xi}_{n}-\xi_{p}\big{)}, embodied in Theorem 1, differ substantially from the regular case in that local estimation of F𝐹F over a shrinking neighbourhood of size Op​((b​ℓ)−1/2)subscript𝑂𝑝superscript𝑏ℓ12O_{p}\big{(}(b\ell)^{-1/2}\big{)} around ξpsubscript𝜉𝑝\xi_{p} incurs an error of order n−1/2​(b​ℓ)1/4superscript𝑛12superscript𝑏ℓ14n^{-1/2}(b\ell)^{1/4}, which favours a small b𝑏b and precludes MBB from yielding an optimal convergence rate.

4 Relevance to Coverage Error

Define

G^n​(x)=ℙ​(b​ℓ​(ξn∗−ξ~n)≤x|X1,…,Xn)subscript^𝐺𝑛𝑥ℙ𝑏ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑛subscript~𝜉𝑛conditional𝑥subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛\hat{G}_{n}(x)={\mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{b\ell}(\xi_{n}^{*}-\tilde{\xi}_{n})\leq x|X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}\right)

and let Δ​(n,b,ℓ)Δ𝑛𝑏ℓ\Delta(n,b,\ell) be defined by

G^n​(x)=Φ​(x​f​(ξp)/σ​(ξp))+Δ​(n,b,ℓ).subscript^𝐺𝑛𝑥Φ𝑥𝑓subscript𝜉𝑝𝜎subscript𝜉𝑝Δ𝑛𝑏ℓ\hat{G}_{n}(x)=\Phi\left(xf(\xi_{p})/\sigma(\xi_{p})\right)+\Delta(n,b,\ell). (4)

Our main results in § 3 establish the asymptotic order of Δ​(n,b,ℓ)Δ𝑛𝑏ℓ\Delta(n,b,\ell) and derive the optimal orders of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) which minimise that order.

A level α𝛼\alpha lower percentile confidence interval for ξpsubscript𝜉𝑝\xi_{p} is given by

[ξ^n−n−1/2​G^n−1​(α),∞).subscript^𝜉𝑛superscript𝑛12superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑛1𝛼[\hat{\xi}_{n}-n^{-1/2}\hat{G}_{n}^{-1}(\alpha),\infty).

Noting from (4) that

G^n−1​(α)=Φ−1​(α)​σ​(ξp)/f​(ξp)+Op​(Δ​(n,b,ℓ)),superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑛1𝛼superscriptΦ1𝛼𝜎subscript𝜉𝑝𝑓subscript𝜉𝑝subscript𝑂𝑝Δ𝑛𝑏ℓ\hat{G}_{n}^{-1}(\alpha)=\Phi^{-1}(\alpha)\sigma(\xi_{p})/f(\xi_{p})+O_{p}\left(\Delta(n,b,\ell)\right),

and using (8) from § 7, which follows from standard asymptotic properties of Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} for dependent data (Lahiri and Sun, 2009), we obtain that

ℙ​(ξp≥ξ^n−n−1/2​G^n−1​(α))ℙsubscript𝜉𝑝subscript^𝜉𝑛superscript𝑛12superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑛1𝛼\displaystyle{\mathbb{P}}\left(\xi_{p}\geq\hat{\xi}_{n}-n^{-1/2}\hat{G}_{n}^{-1}(\alpha)\right) =ℙ​(n​(ξ^n−ξp)≤Φ−1​(α)​σ​(ξp)/f​(ξp))absentℙ𝑛subscript^𝜉𝑛subscript𝜉𝑝superscriptΦ1𝛼𝜎subscript𝜉𝑝𝑓subscript𝜉𝑝\displaystyle={\mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{n}(\hat{\xi}_{n}-\xi_{p})\leq\Phi^{-1}(\alpha)\sigma(\xi_{p})/f(\xi_{p})\right)
+O​(Δ​(n,b,ℓ))𝑂Δ𝑛𝑏ℓ\displaystyle\qquad+O\left(\Delta(n,b,\ell)\right)
=α+O​(Δ​(n,b,ℓ)+n−1/2)absent𝛼𝑂Δ𝑛𝑏ℓsuperscript𝑛12\displaystyle=\alpha+O\left(\Delta(n,b,\ell)+n^{-1/2}\right)

Thus, minimising the order of Δ​(n,b,ℓ)Δ𝑛𝑏ℓ\Delta(n,b,\ell) also minimises the order of the coverage error.

5 Practical Procedure for Selecting Optimal (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell)

Setting b=⌊c1​n1/3⌋𝑏subscript𝑐1superscript𝑛13b=\lfloor c_{1}n^{1/3}\rfloor and ℓ=⌊c2​n1/3⌋ℓsubscript𝑐2superscript𝑛13\ell=\lfloor c_{2}n^{1/3}\rfloor, the objective is to find the optimal pair of positive constants (c1,c2)subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2(c_{1},c_{2}) which minimise the estimation error of G^n​(x)subscript^𝐺𝑛𝑥\hat{G}_{n}(x), or coverage error under some obvious modification of the procedure. Note from (4) and (8) that

G^n​(x)−Gn​(x)=Δ​(n,⌊c1​n1/3⌋,⌊c2​n1/3⌋)​{1+op​(1)}.subscript^𝐺𝑛𝑥subscript𝐺𝑛𝑥Δ𝑛subscript𝑐1superscript𝑛13subscript𝑐2superscript𝑛131subscript𝑜𝑝1\hat{G}_{n}(x)-G_{n}(x)=\Delta\left(n,\lfloor c_{1}n^{1/3}\rfloor,\lfloor c_{2}n^{1/3}\rfloor\right)\{1+o_{p}(1)\}. (5)

Define, for c1,c2>0subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐20c_{1},c_{2}>0 and a fixed ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0,

δn​(c1,c2)=𝔼​|Δ​(n,⌊c1​n1/3⌋,⌊c2​n1/3⌋)|ρ.subscript𝛿𝑛subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2𝔼superscriptΔ𝑛subscript𝑐1superscript𝑛13subscript𝑐2superscript𝑛13𝜌\delta_{n}(c_{1},c_{2})={\mathbb{E}}\left|\Delta\left(n,\lfloor c_{1}n^{1/3}\rfloor,\lfloor c_{2}n^{1/3}\rfloor\right)\right|^{\rho}.

Then the Lρsubscript𝐿𝜌L_{\rho} estimation error of G^n​(x)subscript^𝐺𝑛𝑥\hat{G}_{n}(x) has the expansion

𝔼​|G^n​(x)−Gn​(x)|ρ=δn​(c1,c2)​{1+o​(1)}.𝔼superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑛𝑥subscript𝐺𝑛𝑥𝜌subscript𝛿𝑛subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐21𝑜1{\mathbb{E}}\left|\hat{G}_{n}(x)-G_{n}(x)\right|^{\rho}=\delta_{n}(c_{1},c_{2})\{1+o(1)\}. (6)

We wish to minimise δn​(c1,c2)subscript𝛿𝑛subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2\delta_{n}(c_{1},c_{2}) with respect to c1,c2subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2c_{1},c_{2}.

Let M𝑀M be a subsample size satisfying M=o​(n)𝑀𝑜𝑛M=o(n) and M→∞→𝑀M\rightarrow\infty. Let G^M(j)​(x)superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑀𝑗𝑥\hat{G}_{M}^{(j)}(x) be constructed analogously to G^n​(x)subscript^𝐺𝑛𝑥\hat{G}_{n}(x), with the complete sample (X1,…,Xn)subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}) replaced by the j𝑗jth block of M𝑀M consecutive observations drawn from (X1,…,Xn)subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}), for j=1,n−M+1𝑗1𝑛𝑀1j=1,n-M+1. Then we have, analogous to (5), that

G^M(j)​(x)−GM​(x)=Δ(j)​(M,⌊c1​M1/3⌋,⌊c2​M1/3⌋)​{1+op​(1)},superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑀𝑗𝑥subscript𝐺𝑀𝑥superscriptΔ𝑗𝑀subscript𝑐1superscript𝑀13subscript𝑐2superscript𝑀131subscript𝑜𝑝1\hat{G}_{M}^{(j)}(x)-G_{M}(x)=\Delta^{(j)}\left(M,\lfloor c_{1}M^{1/3}\rfloor,\lfloor c_{2}M^{1/3}\rfloor\right)\{1+o_{p}(1)\}, (7)

where Δ(j)​(⋅)superscriptΔ𝑗⋅\Delta^{(j)}(\cdot) denotes the version of Δ​(⋅)Δ⋅\Delta(\cdot) obtained from the j𝑗jth subsample. Define

E​r​r​(c1,c2)=(n−M+1)−1​∑j|G^M(j)​(x)−G^n​(x)|ρ.𝐸𝑟𝑟subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2superscript𝑛𝑀11subscript𝑗superscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑀𝑗𝑥subscript^𝐺𝑛𝑥𝜌Err(c_{1},c_{2})=(n-M+1)^{-1}\sum_{j}\left|\hat{G}_{M}^{(j)}(x)-\hat{G}_{n}(x)\right|^{\rho}.

Using (8), (5) and (7), we have

G^M(j)​(x)−G^n​(x)superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑀𝑗𝑥subscript^𝐺𝑛𝑥\displaystyle\hat{G}_{M}^{(j)}(x)-\hat{G}_{n}(x) =GM​(x)+Δ(j)​(M,⌊c1​M1/3⌋,⌊c2​M1/3⌋)​{1+op​(1)}absentsubscript𝐺𝑀𝑥superscriptΔ𝑗𝑀subscript𝑐1superscript𝑀13subscript𝑐2superscript𝑀131subscript𝑜𝑝1\displaystyle=G_{M}(x)+\Delta^{(j)}\left(M,\lfloor c_{1}M^{1/3}\rfloor,\lfloor c_{2}M^{1/3}\rfloor\right)\{1+o_{p}(1)\}
−Gn​(x)−Δ​(n,⌊c1​n1/3⌋,⌊c2​n1/3⌋)​{1+op​(1)}subscript𝐺𝑛𝑥Δ𝑛subscript𝑐1superscript𝑛13subscript𝑐2superscript𝑛131subscript𝑜𝑝1\displaystyle\qquad-G_{n}(x)-\Delta\left(n,\lfloor c_{1}n^{1/3}\rfloor,\lfloor c_{2}n^{1/3}\rfloor\right)\{1+o_{p}(1)\}
=Δ(j)​(M,⌊c1​M1/3⌋,⌊c2​M1/3⌋)​{1+op​(1)}.absentsuperscriptΔ𝑗𝑀subscript𝑐1superscript𝑀13subscript𝑐2superscript𝑀131subscript𝑜𝑝1\displaystyle=\Delta^{(j)}\left(M,\lfloor c_{1}M^{1/3}\rfloor,\lfloor c_{2}M^{1/3}\rfloor\right)\{1+o_{p}(1)\}.

It follows that

E​r​r​(c1,c2)𝐸𝑟𝑟subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2\displaystyle Err(c_{1},c_{2}) =\displaystyle= (n−M+1)−1​∑j|Δ(j)​(M,⌊c1​M1/3⌋,⌊c2​M1/3⌋)|ρ​{1+op​(1)}superscript𝑛𝑀11subscript𝑗superscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑗𝑀subscript𝑐1superscript𝑀13subscript𝑐2superscript𝑀13𝜌1subscript𝑜𝑝1\displaystyle(n-M+1)^{-1}\sum_{j}\left|\Delta^{(j)}\left(M,\lfloor c_{1}M^{1/3}\rfloor,\lfloor c_{2}M^{1/3}\rfloor\right)\right|^{\rho}\{1+o_{p}(1)\}
=\displaystyle= δM​(c1,c2)​{1+op​(1)}.subscript𝛿𝑀subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐21subscript𝑜𝑝1\displaystyle\delta_{M}(c_{1},c_{2})\{1+o_{p}(1)\}.

If we assume, as is typical, that δn​(c1,c2)subscript𝛿𝑛subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2\delta_{n}(c_{1},c_{2}) has a leading term of the form β​(c1,c2)​n−γ𝛽subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2superscript𝑛𝛾\beta(c_{1},c_{2})n^{-\gamma} for some function β​(⋅)𝛽⋅\beta(\cdot) independent of n𝑛n, then E​r​r​(c1,c2)𝐸𝑟𝑟subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2Err(c_{1},c_{2}), δM​(c1,c2)subscript𝛿𝑀subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2\delta_{M}(c_{1},c_{2}) and δn​(c1,c2)subscript𝛿𝑛subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2\delta_{n}(c_{1},c_{2}) are all minimised at asymptotically the same (c1,c2)subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2(c_{1},c_{2}). Thus, an empirical procedure for choosing (c1,c2)subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2(c_{1},c_{2}), and hence choosing (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell), may be based on the minimisation of E​r​r​(c1,c2)𝐸𝑟𝑟subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2Err(c_{1},c_{2}).

This procedure constructs the error estimate E​r​r​(c1,c2)𝐸𝑟𝑟subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2Err(c_{1},c_{2}) by considering all n−M+1𝑛𝑀1n-M+1 subsamples of M𝑀M consecutive points drawn from the original data sample, and is therefore computationally expensive. However, the argument supporting minimization of this quantity actually only requires that the number of subsamples used in the construction should grow with sample size n𝑛n. In practice, therefore, it is reasonable to evaluate the error measure E​r​r​(c1,c2)𝐸𝑟𝑟subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2Err(c_{1},c_{2}) using a smaller set of subsamples: in the numerical illustration given below, 20 subsamples, equally spaced along the data series (X1,…,Xn)subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}), are used, allowing rapid evaluation of the error estimate.

6 Examples

To illustrate the benefits of optimally choosing (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell), we consider three very general examples. For concreteness, we consider p=1/2𝑝12p=1/2, and simulate the mean squared errors (MSEs) of hybrid block bootstrap estimators of Gn​(u)subscript𝐺𝑛𝑢G_{n}(u) for particular choices of u𝑢u. The true reference values of Gn​(⋅)subscript𝐺𝑛⋅G_{n}(\cdot) are approximated via massive simulation (5×1065superscript1065\times 10^{6} replications). For each of the sample sizes n=200𝑛200n=200, n=500𝑛500n=500, and n=1000𝑛1000n=1000, all entries in the included tables and heatmaps are based on 20,0002000020,000 replications, with 20,0002000020,000 bootstrap samples used within each replication, unless otherwise stated. For n=2,000𝑛2000n=2,000, the number of replications and bootstrap samples are each 10,0001000010,000. For convenience, Table 1 provides some reference values of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) for MBB for the sample sizes we consider. This facilitates comparison with the MBB choice of b=⌊n/ℓ⌋𝑏𝑛ℓb=\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor for a range of values of ℓℓ\ell. In particular, we give values for ℓℓ\ell approximately equal to n1/2superscript𝑛12n^{1/2} (not optimal), n1/3superscript𝑛13n^{1/3} (thought to be optimal), n1/4superscript𝑛14n^{1/4}, and n1/5superscript𝑛15n^{1/5}.

Example 1 (ARMA(1,1)).

Suppose that the observations are generated according to an ARMA (1,1) model

Xt−0.4​X(t−1)=ϵt+0.3​ϵ(t−1),subscript𝑋𝑡0.4subscript𝑋𝑡1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡0.3subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡1X_{t}-0.4X_{(t-1)}=\epsilon_{t}+0.3\epsilon_{(t-1)},

with ϵtsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon_{t} independent, identically distributed N​(0,1)𝑁01N(0,1). The strong mixing condition is satisfied with an exponential rate (Lahiri, 2003, Example 6.1). An initial X0subscript𝑋0X_{0} is sampled according to the marginal distribution, i.e. X0∼N​(0,1.5833)similar-tosubscript𝑋0𝑁01.5833X_{0}\sim N(0,1.5833), and ϵ0∼N​(0,1)similar-tosubscriptitalic-ϵ0𝑁01\epsilon_{0}\sim N(0,1).

With p=1/2𝑝12p=1/2, we have ξp=0subscript𝜉𝑝0\xi_{p}=0. We simulate the MSE in estimation of Gn​(1)subscript𝐺𝑛1G_{n}(1) over a range of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell). The true value being estimated was computed (by massive simulation, as described) as Gn​(1)≈0.67978subscript𝐺𝑛10.67978G_{n}(1)\approx 0.67978. The heat map in Figure 2 plots MSE for n=200𝑛200n=200, over a grid of values of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell). The heat map clearly illustrates the sub-optimality of b=1𝑏1b=1, the subsampling bootstrap. The minimum MSE is 0.00472, with (b,ℓ)=(6,8)𝑏ℓ68(b,\ell)=(6,8). By contrast, the minimum MSE for the MBB is 0.00637, with (b,ℓ)=(33,6)𝑏ℓ336(b,\ell)=(33,6), and the subsampling bootstrap, which fixes b=1𝑏1b=1, has minimum MSE of 0.00754, with ℓ=14ℓ14\ell=14.

We also compute the values of the pair (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) which minimize MSE for other sample sizes, n=500,1000𝑛5001000n=500,1000, and 200020002000. These results are shown in Table 2. Comparing with Table 1, we note that the MSE-minimizing pair (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) for each n𝑛n uses an ℓℓ\ell strictly greater than n1/3superscript𝑛13n^{1/3} and a b𝑏b much less than ⌊n/ℓ⌋𝑛ℓ\lfloor n/\ell\rfloor. Additionally, the MSE-minimizing value of b𝑏b is much larger than 111.

The theory says that the hybrid MBB has an error rate in estimation of Gn​(1)subscript𝐺𝑛1G_{n}(1) of n−1/3superscript𝑛13n^{-1/3}, so we should expect the MSE to decrease at rate n−2/3superscript𝑛23n^{-2/3}. In fact, a regression of log⁡(M​S​E)𝑀𝑆𝐸\log(MSE) on log⁡(n)𝑛\log(n) for the values reported in Table 2 has slope −0.68850.6885-0.6885, which is not far off −2/323-2/3. The heatmap illustrates that the subsampling and MBB choices of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) are suboptimal.

For the current problem, of estimation of the sampling distribution of the sample quantile, there is therefore clear theoretical and practical advantage in using the hybrid block bootstrap, b​ℓ<n,b≠1formulae-sequence𝑏ℓ𝑛𝑏1b\ell<n,b\neq 1, over the moving block bootstrap. Remark 2 indicates, by contrast, that we might expect to see little difference, in estimation error terms, between the hybrid block bootstrap procedure and MBB if, instead, we are interested in estimation of ℙ​{n​(Fn​(x)−F​(x))≤y}ℙ𝑛subscript𝐹𝑛𝑥𝐹𝑥𝑦{\mathbb{P}}\{\sqrt{n}\big{(}F_{n}(x)-{F}(x)\big{)}\leq y\}. This was verified by considering, for all combinations of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell), the MSE of the estimator ℙ​{b​ℓ​(Fn∗​(x)−F~n​(x))≤y|X1,…,Xn}ℙconditional-set𝑏ℓsubscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑛𝑥subscript~𝐹𝑛𝑥𝑦subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛{\mathbb{P}}\{\sqrt{b\ell}\big{(}F^{*}_{n}(x)-\tilde{F}_{n}(x)\big{)}\leq y\Big{|}X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}\}, for x=0𝑥0x=0, so that F​(x)=0.5𝐹𝑥0.5F(x)=0.5, and y=0.9𝑦0.9y=0.9, for which the quantity being estimated ≈0.89501absent0.89501\approx 0.89501, for sample size n=100𝑛100n=100. Based on 20,000 replications, with 20,000 bootstrap samples being used in construction of the estimator for each, the minimum MSE achieved by MBB is 0.00084, with (b,ℓ)=(25,4)𝑏ℓ254(b,\ell)=(25,4). This is very similar to the overall minimum MSE of 0.00082, seen for (b,ℓ)=(18,5)𝑏ℓ185(b,\ell)=(18,5). The minimum MSE of the subsampling bootstrap, b=1𝑏1b=1, is 0.00334, substantially larger, when ℓ=7ℓ7\ell=7. This same picture was seen for n=200𝑛200n=200, when, for the same values x=0,y=0.9formulae-sequence𝑥0𝑦0.9x=0,y=0.9, the true probability being estimated ≈0.87781absent0.87781\approx 0.87781. Simulation shows that the minimum MSE of MBB is then 0.00108, with (b,ℓ)=(28,7)𝑏ℓ287(b,\ell)=(28,7), with the same minimum MSE for the hybrid block bootstrap, achieved for (b,ℓ)=(30,6)𝑏ℓ306(b,\ell)=(30,6). Here the subsampling bootstrap yields an optimal MSE of 0.00227 when ℓ=8ℓ8\ell=8. These illustrative figures confirm that the hybrid block bootstrap has little advantage over MBB in error terms for this problem.

Example 2 (Nonlinear ARMA(2,3)).

Let {Xt}t∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑡ℤ\{X_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{Z}} be a sequence from the ARMA(2,3) process

Xt−0.1​X(t−1)+0.3​X(t−2)=ϵt+0.1​ϵ(t−1)+0.2​ϵ(t−2)−0.1​ϵ(t−3).subscript𝑋𝑡0.1subscript𝑋𝑡10.3subscript𝑋𝑡2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡0.1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡10.2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡20.1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡3X_{t}-0.1X_{(t-1)}+0.3X_{(t-2)}=\epsilon_{t}+0.1\epsilon_{(t-1)}+0.2\epsilon_{(t-2)}-0.1\epsilon_{(t-3)}.

As noted by Lahiri (2003, Example 6.1), such a sequence is strong mixing with exponentially decaying mixing coefficients. To simulate from this model, we initiate by generating X0,X−1subscript𝑋0subscript𝑋1X_{0},X_{-1} from the marginal N​(0,v2)𝑁0superscript𝑣2N(0,v^{2}) distribution, which has v2=1.0776superscript𝑣21.0776v^{2}=1.0776, with ϵ0,ϵ−1,ϵ−2subscriptitalic-ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon_{0},\epsilon_{-1},\epsilon_{-2} independent N​(0,1)𝑁01N(0,1). The nonlinear model we consider is the square transformation of the above ARMA process,

Yt=Xt2.subscript𝑌𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡2Y_{t}=X_{t}^{2}.

The square transformation above preserves the strong mixing property and also preserves the mixing rate. Therefore, Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t} is strong mixing with the same exponential rate as Xtsubscript𝑋𝑡X_{t}. The interested reader is referred to Fan and Yao (2003, p. 69) or Davis and Mikosch (2009, p. 258). As with the previous example, we consider p=1/2𝑝12p=1/2, and thus ξpsubscript𝜉𝑝\xi_{p} satisfies

ℙ​(Yt=Xt2≤ξp)=1/2,ℙsubscript𝑌𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡2subscript𝜉𝑝12{\mathbb{P}}(Y_{t}=X_{t}^{2}\leq\xi_{p})=1/2,

implying ξp=(0.675​v)2subscript𝜉𝑝superscript0.675𝑣2\xi_{p}=(0.675v)^{2}. The simulation approximation to the true value is Gn​(−1.5)≈0.09276subscript𝐺𝑛1.50.09276G_{n}(-1.5)\approx 0.09276.

The heatmap of Figure 3 shows again that the subsampling and MBB choices of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) are suboptimal from the perspective of minimizing MSE.

In Figure 4 we display the coverage error of lower percentile confidence intervals, as described in Section 4, of nominal 90% coverage. We observe that there is undercoverage for most choices of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell), sometimes very substantial, though there is overcoverage in a few cases. Appropriate choice of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) can yield limits with exactly the required coverage.

As proof of concept of the adaptive procedure for choice of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) described in Section 5, we consider estimation of Gn​(1)≈0.80952subscript𝐺𝑛10.80952G_{n}(1)\approx 0.80952, for sample size n=512𝑛512n=512. We restrict to candidate values c1,c2∈{0.5,0.75,1.0,1.5,2.0}subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐20.50.751.01.52.0c_{1},c_{2}\in\{0.5,0.75,1.0,1.5,2.0\}, corresponding to adaptive choice of b,ℓ∈{4,6,8,12,16}𝑏ℓ4681216b,\ell\in\{4,6,8,12,16\}. Table 3 shows the MSE in estimation of Gn​(1)subscript𝐺𝑛1G_{n}(1) over 2500 replications for each combination of (c1,c2)subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2(c_{1},c_{2}). By contrast, the MSE obtained by minimization of E​r​r​(c1,c2)𝐸𝑟𝑟subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2Err(c_{1},c_{2}) for each replication, using 20 subsamples of size M=64𝑀64M=64 in construction of this error quantity, was 0.00189. The adaptive method clearly yields an MSE that is far from optimal in this setting, but outperforms the procedure which fixes b,ℓ𝑏ℓb,\ell to larger values among those being considered.

The adaptive procedure is seen to perform better with increasing sample size. Table 4 provides analagous results for sample size n=1728𝑛1728n=1728, for which Gn​(1)≈0.81125subscript𝐺𝑛10.81125G_{n}(1)\approx 0.81125. Using M=512𝑀512M=512 in the minimization of E​r​r​(c1,c2)𝐸𝑟𝑟subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2Err(c_{1},c_{2}) over the same range of c1,c2subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2c_{1},c_{2}, now corresponding to adaptive choice of b,ℓ∈{6,9,12,18,24}𝑏ℓ69121824b,\ell\in\{6,9,12,18,24\}, and again using just 20 subsamples of length M𝑀M in evaluation of E​r​r​(c1,c2)𝐸𝑟𝑟subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2Err(c_{1},c_{2}), the MSE of the adaptively chosen estimator over the 2500 replications was observed as 0.00066, much closer to optimal. Further tuning of the adaptive procedure certainly seems worthwhile as a means of providing an effective automatic choice of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) for the hybrid block bootstrap and will be pursued elsewhere.

Next we construct a process whose mixing coefficients decay at a polynomial rate, but not an exponential rate. This is accomplished through Theorem 2.1 of Chanda (1974); see also Bandyopadhyay (2006) and §3 of Chen et al. (2016).

Example 3 (Polynomial Mixing Rate).

Let the sequence {Xt}t∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑡ℤ\{X_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{Z}} be generated according to

Xt=∑j=0∞cj​Zt−j,subscript𝑋𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗0subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝑍𝑡𝑗X_{t}=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}c_{j}Z_{t-j},

where the Zisubscript𝑍𝑖Z_{i} are independent, identically distributed N​(0,1)𝑁01N(0,1) and cj=(1j+1)νsubscript𝑐𝑗superscript1𝑗1𝜈c_{j}=(\tfrac{1}{j+1})^{\nu}. Then Xtsubscript𝑋𝑡X_{t} is strong mixing with a polynomial rate, and Chanda (1974) may be used to deduce that β<ν−2𝛽𝜈2\beta<\nu-2.

In practice, we cannot simulate from the above process exactly because it is expressed as an infinite series. Therefore, we approximate the process by truncating the series at 100 terms, which means that in reality Xtsubscript𝑋𝑡X_{t} is approximated by a very high order MA process. For our numerical example, ν=10.0𝜈10.0\nu=10.0 and n=200𝑛200n=200. As before, we consider p=1/2𝑝12p=1/2, corresponding to ξp=0subscript𝜉𝑝0\xi_{p}=0. Simulation yields an approximation to the true value Gn​(2)≈0.95229subscript𝐺𝑛20.95229G_{n}(2)\approx 0.95229. The heatmap for this example shown in Figure 5 is based on 10,000 replications, and 10,000 bootstrap samples for each replication of the experiment.

As with the previous two examples, the heatmap supports our finding of suboptimality of the choices of (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) suggested by the subsampling bootstrap and the MBB.

7 Proofs

In what follows we denote by C𝐶C a generic positive constant independent of n𝑛n. Denote by ΦΦ\Phi and ϕitalic-ϕ\phi the standard normal distribution and density functions, respectively. Standard asymptotic properties (e.g. Lahiri and Sun (2009)) of Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} for dependent data can be invoked to show that, for any x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R},

ℙ​(n​(ξ^n−ξp)≤x)=Φ​(x​f​(ξp)/σ​(ξp))+O​(n−1/2),ℙ𝑛subscript^𝜉𝑛subscript𝜉𝑝𝑥Φ𝑥𝑓subscript𝜉𝑝𝜎subscript𝜉𝑝𝑂superscript𝑛12{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{n}\big{(}\hat{\xi}_{n}-\xi_{p}\big{)}\leq x\Big{)}=\Phi\big{(}xf(\xi_{p})/\sigma(\xi_{p})\big{)}+O(n^{-1/2}), (8)

where σ​(x)2=limn→∞​Var​(n​Fn​(x))=∑t=−∞∞Cov​(𝟏​{X0≤x},𝟏​{Xt≤x})𝜎superscript𝑥2→𝑛Var𝑛subscript𝐹𝑛𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑡Cov1subscript𝑋0𝑥1subscript𝑋𝑡𝑥\sigma(x)^{2}=\underset{n\rightarrow\infty}{\lim}\text{Var}\big{(}\sqrt{n}F_{n}(x)\big{)}=\sum_{t=-\infty}^{\infty}\mbox{\rm Cov}\,\big{(}\boldsymbol{1}\{X_{0}\leq x\},\boldsymbol{1}\{X_{t}\leq x\}\big{)}.

We first state a lemma which is a special case of Sun and Lahiri’s (2006) Lemma 5.3.

Define, for any r>0𝑟0r>0, ℬr​(ξp)=[ξp−r,ξp+r]subscriptℬ𝑟subscript𝜉𝑝subscript𝜉𝑝𝑟subscript𝜉𝑝𝑟\mathscr{B}_{r}(\xi_{p})=[\xi_{p}-r,\xi_{p}+r].

Proof of Lemma 3:

Define mn=⌈nβ−12​(β+1)−3​δ​ϵ1−12​(β+1)−δ⌉subscript𝑚𝑛superscript𝑛𝛽12𝛽13𝛿superscriptitalic-ϵ112𝛽1𝛿m_{n}=\left\lceil n^{\,\frac{\beta-1}{2(\beta+1)}-3\delta}\epsilon^{1-\frac{1}{2(\beta+1)}-\delta}\right\rceil and ϵn=ϵ/mnsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛italic-ϵsubscript𝑚𝑛\epsilon_{n}=\epsilon/m_{n}. Then we have

Similar arguments show also that ℙ​(F~n​(ξ~n)≤p−nδ​ε​(n,ℓ))=o​(1)ℙsubscript~𝐹𝑛subscript~𝜉𝑛𝑝superscript𝑛𝛿𝜀𝑛ℓ𝑜1{\mathbb{P}}\big{(}\tilde{F}_{n}(\tilde{\xi}_{n})\leq p-n^{\delta}\varepsilon(n,\ell)\big{)}=o(1), which completes the proof of part (ii).

8 Conclusion

In the absence of exact, finite-sample results, accurate estimation of quantiles is essential for implementation of statistical inference procedures. As sample quantiles are non-smooth functionals, conventional bootstrap theory for the smooth function model does not apply to estimation of their distribution. In dependent data settings, with some notable exceptions, little is known about the block bootstrap for distribution estimation of sample quantiles. In this paper we have established a general optimality theory for block bootstrap procedures in such settings under strong mixing conditions, and we have shown that a hybrid block bootstrap is optimal, in the sense of having the fastest convergence rate for distribution estimation. In addition, of course, since the hybrid block bootstrap is based on bootstrap samples of smaller size than the data sample, it provides computational advantage over MBB. How one should choose (b,ℓ)𝑏ℓ(b,\ell) in a given application to capture the good theoretical properties of the hybrid block bootstrap requires further consideration. We have provided discussion of an empirical scheme that seems fruitful for this purpose and which will be further developed and refined elsewhere.
